General Information.name: Yusuf Ali
General Information.summary: A German-born theoretical physicist, widely ranked among the greatest and most influential scientists of all time

Involvements: TAMU Computing Society, TAMUhack, Aggie Artificial Intelligence Society, A&M Club Soccer

Experience.name: LearnToBot
highlights: Teaching over 100 students how to build and code problem-solving robots in weekly camps.
Designing and testing software/hardware projects for use in future camps and classes.
Hosting robotics camps for Destination Imagination teams in our community.

Experience.name: Muse Mantra School of Music & Arts
highlights: Assisted in developing the school website and currently building a web application to streamline the student registration process.
Building a web application with the DW Spectrum & Pike13 APIs to streamline the student registration process.
Organizing quarterly audits of the school database to analyze student enrollment and retention.

Experience.name: Laredo Sports Medicine Clinic
highlights: Developed machine learning algorithms for Stryker Mako surgical machines and worked with departments in the clinic including research and development, physical training, and marketing.
Met with professionals involved in the biotechnology industry from Texas A&M International University.

awards.title: Global Finals: 3rd Place Award
awards.summary: Our LearnToBot Destination Imagination team received this award for placing 3rd in the Fine Arts Challenge at Destination Imagination’s annual competition. To achieve this award, our team’s project also won its district and state competitions.

awards.title: The Woodforest Bank Triathlon Finisher
awards.awarder: The Woodlands Township Parks and Recreation Department
awards.summary: I received this award for completing The Woodforest Bank TRI. The triathlon consisted of a 500-meter open swim, a 12.8-mile bike ride, and a 5-kilometer run.

awards.title: UTCS Robotics Champion
awards.awarder: The University of Texas at Austin Department of Computer Science
awards.summary: I achieved this award for ranking first place in UT Austin's annual robotics competition. This event consisted of building and coding a robocar to traverse through a race track in the fastest time possible.

awards.title: NHSMUN Award of Distinction in Research & Preparation
awards.awarder: National High School Model United Nations
awards.summary: Our club was selected for this honor based on research papers we had written for the NHSMUN 2022 Conference.

awards.title: NHSMUN Award of Merit
awards.awarder: National High School Model United Nations
awards.summary: My team was recognized for this honor based on our individual performance during the NHSMUN 2022 Conference.

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Responsible for finding contributors, assisting customers, and sorting donations around the store.
Used the store's earnings to distribute a year's worth of foodstuffs and kitchenware to 100+ local workers!

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
